newsitem.title: INDIA: Indian call easy on low demand, gilts sharply up.
newsitem.headline: Indian call easy on low demand, gilts sharply up.

text.p: Indian call money rates ended Friday unchanged from the day's opening on poor demand at 0.10-0.50 percent in lacklustre trade, dealers said.
Stray deals also took place at 1.0 percent, they said.
"Call market was very bad today...rates were below 0.50 percent almost throughout," a dealer at a state-run bank said.
"Today's repo auction is unlikely to have any impact on call rates, even if Reserve Bank of India (RBI) mops up 30-35 billion rupees," he said.
"Call rates should be between 2.0 percent and 3.0 percent for the rest of this fortnight," he added.
The RBI accpeted bids for 15.20 billion rupees at a four-day repo auction of government securities held on Friday.

"The market is keenly awaiting steps in the forthcoming credit policy to bring down interest rates and boost credit off-take without fuelling inflation," R. Narayan dealer at Bank of Nova Scotia said.
The RBI announces its credit and monetary policy for the first half of 1997/98 (April-March) on April 15.
Narayan said the government securities market was in the grip of a bull run which resulted in prices of stocks of all maturities rising by 20 to 40 paise.
Ten-year paper traded on Friday at a yield of 13.30 to 13.35 percent compared to last week's 13.65 percent, he said.
Friday's trades on the National Stock Exchange were worth 5.02 billion rupees against Thursday's 6.07 billion rupees, dealers said.
Treasury bills maturing in July traded at a yield of 8.05 percent yield against its last yield of 8.15 percent, dealers said.
